Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Role Of Road Systems In Social Definition And Integration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The fundamental goal of this research is to explore the social implications in the development of the urban layout by studying the road network of the ancient city of Angamuco (250-1530 CE), located in the core-area of the Purépecha Empire (Lake Pátzcuaro Basin), Michoacán. It will provide insight into our general understanding of how a city emerges, develops, is inhabited and experienced by its residents, and the roles that roads play during these processes. Under the guidance of Dr. Marcos Llobera, Rodrigo Solinis-Casparius will integrate spatial and image analysis with archaeological survey and excavation to: (1) identify road segments, pathways, intersections and other associated movement technology; (2) determine the relative temporal sequencing and configuration of roads, and; (3) classify roads according to their morphology, construction, configuration, and experiential properties. This will permit rigorous evaluation of: a) changes in patterns of urbanization through thirteen centuries of habitation, and b) the influence of the State and commoners in the creation, establishment and use of the movement network of Angamuco. Ultimately, researchers will produce new insights that are relevant to a wide range of disciplines interested in community formation, material agency, and the emergence and transformation of urban spaces.

This project will suggest a conceptual framework to explore different scales of social interaction and organization in western Mexico by incorporating approaches used in Mesoamerica, the Middle East, Southeast Asia and the Mediterranean to assess intra-site mobility and urbanization processes. This research will directly contribute in two ways. Methodologically, this study will provide techniques to better identify ancient urban roads by their manufacture technology, morphology, connectivity and accessibility. It will also test and develop a methodology to better understand the chronological sequencing of roads implementing Network Analysis, ceramic seriation and absolute dating (C14). Analytically, this project will provide a detailed typology of urban roads, an interpretative ground to explore the social organization and the urbanization process of Angamuco, and the impact of Purépecha Empire's influence in the Lake Pátzcuaro Basin area. The results of this project will be used as a basis for continuing investigation of intra-site mobility, accessibility and interaction, as well as the relationship between humans and their landscape in Mesoamerica and elsewhere.

More broadly, this project will contribute to increasing the ways in which archaeological heritage is valued for scientists and the importance of protecting it by developing educational and outreach activities in communities located near the archaeological site in Mexico and in the U.S. These actions will add to the conservation efforts of the heritage council community center in Tzintzuntzan and include: a) generating informative materials (including a community report in Spanish) discussing the history of the site and the archaeological practice, b) offering guided site tours for community members, and c) engaging in talks and presentations to educators and students in local schools and at local events. Finally, working with the Legacies of Resilience Project (LORE-LPB), this research will contribute to the training of young scholars from different backgrounds and nurture international relationships between Mexican and American institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human settlements are very distinct and complex socio-cultural systems and are expressed at many scales of organization, production, distribution, and consumer practices. Roads are a part of the spatial expression of this system because they define access to and through architecture, resources, and the natural landscape. In Archaeology, roads have most often been seen only as the byproduct of the movement of people and goods. However, roads are structures where individual decisions are regularly influenced by social norms. As such, their use, construction, and maintenance correspond to a combination of complex cultural, economic, and political factors that are determined within community. Studying how roads are created and used in the past, and the potential activities that these may have afforded offers the possibility to better understand fundamental dimensions of socialization and urban development for cities in the past and cities today. 

The goal of this dissertation research (partly funded by this grant) is twofold: first, developing and testing several methods including computational and on the field, to identify and classify ancient roads in the context of archaeological investigation; and second, bringing these results into an analytical framework that allows us explain social and urbanization phenomena from past societies. Ultimately, this research will provide an innovative approach to the study of a body of physical features often disregarded in the discipline that can serve other researches to develop new interpretations for human behavior using the unique case study of Angamuco in Mexico. 

The size (~12km2), complexity (+20,000 buildings), organization, and suggested chronology (200–1530 CE) of this site; suggest that it was an important urban center in the area for over 1500 years before European contact. With this research, I will contribute to understanding the role that Angamuco played political, cultural, and historically in the region and particularly for the period of the Purépecha Empire formation. 

I spent several months directing survey and excavation in the past two years where I mapped a sample of 450 roads and associated features (stairs, entrances, ramps, etc.) of an area of about 10% of the site, excavated several distinct samples of roads and crossroads, collected and analyzed over 2,000 ceramic and lithic fragments, and obtained several radiocarbon dates. 

During this research I have also performed image and computational analysis to identify all possible Prehispanic and manmade roads directly from the Digital Elevation Model (DEM) for the rest of the site. The results account for a road network comprised of more than 5,000 road segments and around 4,500 nodes or crossroads. 

In sum, the preliminary results of all analyses in my research (C14, ceramic analysis, stratigraphy, architecture, network analysis) already confirm that the road network was a fundamental part of the urban plan, that transformation of the landscape and the movement infrastructure was occurring at the earlier stages of inhabitation of the site, that there is a set of variables that can help differentiate between planned and unplanned roads, and that there was an ample diversity of roads in terms of their construction system and possibly their intended use. 

During data collection stage of this research I was able to build bridges between my parent institution (UW) and several Mexican and local institutions. An example of this is the direct and healthy relationship between the INAH-Michoacan office and the Fontezuelas community where the site is located. The INAH-Michoacan office is in charge of foreseeing the proper management and protection of the archaeological site located in the communal lands of the Ejido. They have never met and only after my presence a plan for the proper care of the land and the site has been drafted between the two institutions. An achievement not only desirable but highly challenging that speaks great of the broader impacts value in this research. Similarly I designed and directed workshops, public talks and guided visits to the site and about protection of archaeological heritage as well as intellectual goals and practice of this discipline to local members of the community and general public in Mexico.

The goals and motivations of this project transcend traditional archaeological research questions. While specific to the site of Angamuco, have the potential to bring information about universal human phenomena. This project has been designed incorporating analytical tools from other disciplines like urban studies, architecture, sociology, statistics, spatial analysis, etc. 

Particularly, understanding how cities are socially constructed from a diachronic perspective. The study of a case study that also incorporates evidence of social struggles very well identified (city state, empire formation) and their consequences on daily activities, community and collaborative organization has the potential to promote the incorporation of archaeological findings to other current and relevant social phenomena.
